holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that rule 95 of the Bihar and Orissa Service Code had no application to the facts and circumstances of this case and that the enabling provisions of this rule did not operate as a bar to the plaintiff's action.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we are of the opinion that the High Court was right in holding that rule 95 had no application to the facts and circumstances of this case and that the enabling provisions of this rule did not operate as a bar to the plaintiffs action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismissal by subordinate authority invalid under s.240(3); appeals rejected without reinstatement by appellate authority; post-suit reinstatement by government not under rule's contemplation.

holdings.text: The dismissal of the respondent by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police was contrary to section 240(3) of the Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent here was dismissed by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police, though he was appointed by the Inspector-General of Police. This was clearly contrary to the provisions of section 240 (3) of the Government of India Act, 1935, which provides that no person shall be dismissed from the service of His Majesty by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text prohibits dismissal by authority subordinate to the appointing authority.

holdings.text: A suit for arrears of salary by a civil servant against the State is competent in a civil court.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the learned Solicitor-General that a suit by a public servant against the State for recovery of arrears of salary cannot be maintained in a civil court is again, in our opinion, without substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms Federal Court in Tara Chand; CPC s.60 permits creditor attachment implying enforceable right; English prerogatives inapplicable; PC cases distinguish as not addressing arrears or CPC.

holdings.text: The prerogative right under section 240(1) of the Government of India Act, 1935, to dismiss at pleasure is subject to limitations in other subsections like section 240(3).

anchor.surface_text: It was there held that the prerogative right of the Crown to dismiss its servants at will having been given statutory form in sub-section (1) of section 240 of the Government of India Act, 1935, it could only be exercised subject to the limitations imposed by the remaining sub-sections of that section

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation requires harmonious construction; pleasure not absolute where statute limits.

holdings.text: Rule 95 does not bar suit for arrears as it is merely enabling and inapplicable here.

anchor.surface_text: that the enabling provisions of this rule did not operate as a bar to the plaintiffs action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule applies only to reinstatement by revising/appellate authority after valid proceedings; here invalid dismissal and irregular reinstatement.

holdings.text: Tara Chand Pandit case remains good law and was not dissented from or overruled by Privy Council in I.M. Lall or Suraj Narain Anand.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the matter is covered by the decision of the Federal Court in Tara Chand Pandits case with which we find ourselves in respectful agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PC cases did not consider CPC provisions or directly address arrears claim; point obiter or not argued.

holdings.text: Provisions of CPC section 60 imply civil servant has enforceable right to salary against government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Creditor attachment presupposes debtor's (servant's) right against Crown; inconsistent to deny servant direct suit.

holdings.text: The pleasure doctrine concerns tenure of office only and does not imply salary is bounty or non-enforceable.

anchor.surface_text: The expression concerns itself with the tenure of office of the civil servant and it is not implicit in it that a civil servant serves the Crown ex gratia or that his salary is in the nature of a bounty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive reading; separates tenure from remuneration rights; quantum meruit basis for arrears.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent here was dismissed by the Deputy Inspector-General of Police, though he was appointed by the Inspector-General of Police. This was clearly contrary to the provisions of section 240 (3) of the Government of India Act, 1935, which provides that no person shall be dismissed from the service of His Majesty by an authority subordinate to that by which he was appointed.

For the reasons given above we are of the opinion that the High Court was right in holding that rule 95 had no application to the facts and circumstances of this case and that the enabling provisions of this rule did
